categories.name: Two Pointers
categories.description: Problems that use two pointer technique to solve efficiently

categories.name: Sliding Window
categories.description: Problems involving maintaining a window of elements

categories.name: Dynamic Programming
categories.description: Problems requiring optimal substructure and memoization

categories.name: Trees
categories.description: Binary trees, BST, and tree traversals

questions.title: Two Sum
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice.
questions.problemStatement:
Write a function that takes an array of integers and a target sum, and returns the indices of two numbers that add up to the target.

Constraints:
- 2 <= nums.length <= 10^4
- -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9
- -10^9 <= target <= 10^9
- Only one valid answer exists

examples.explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].
Because nums[1] + nums[2] == 6, we return [1, 2].

hints: Try using a hash map to store numbers you've seen
For each number, check if target - num exists in the map

questions.title: Container With Most Water
questions.introduction: You are given an integer array height of length n. There are n vertical lines drawn such that the two endpoints of the ith line are (i, 0) and (i, height[i]). Find two lines that together with the x-axis form a container that contains the most water.
questions.problemStatement:
Find two lines that together with the x-axis form a container that contains the most water. Return the maximum amount of water a container can store.

Constraints:
- n == height.length
- 2 <= n <= 10^5
- 0 <= height[i] <= 10^4

examples.explanation: The vertical lines are at indices 1 and 8, and they form a container with max area = 49.

hints: Start with two pointers at both ends
Move the pointer with smaller height inward
Calculate area at each step and keep track of maximum

questions.title: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
questions.introduction: Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

Constraints:
- 0 <= s.length <= 5 * 10^4
- s consists of English letters, digits, symbols and spaces.

examples.explanation: The answer is "abc", with the length of 3.
The answer is "b", with the length of 1.

hints: Use sliding window technique
Maintain a set or map to track characters in current window
Expand window by moving right pointer, shrink when duplicate found
questions.spaceComplexity: O(min(m,n)) where m is charset size

questions.title: Binary Search
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers nums which is sorted in ascending order, and an integer target, write a function to search target in nums. If target exists, then return its index. Otherwise, return -1.
questions.problemStatement:
Implement binary search algorithm on a sorted array.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^4
- -10^4 < nums[i], target < 10^4
- All integers in nums are unique
- nums is sorted in ascending order

examples.explanation: 9 exists in nums and its index is 4
2 does not exist in nums so return -1

hints: Use two pointers: left and right
Calculate mid = left + (right - left) / 2
Adjust pointers based on comparison with target

questions.title: Climbing Stairs
questions.introduction: You are climbing a staircase. It takes n steps to reach the top. Each time you can either climb 1 or 2 steps. In how many distinct ways can you climb to the top?
questions.problemStatement:
Calculate the number of distinct ways to climb to the top of a staircase with n steps.

Constraints:
- 1 <= n <= 45

examples.explanation: There are two ways to climb to the top: 1+1 or 2
There are three ways: 1+1+1, 1+2, or 2+1

hints: This is a Fibonacci sequence problem
ways(n) = ways(n-1) + ways(n-2)
Can be solved iteratively with O(1) space

questions.title: Reverse Linked List
questions.introduction: Given the head of a singly linked list, reverse the list, and return the reversed list.
questions.problemStatement:
Reverse a singly linked list.

Constraints:
- The number of nodes in the list is in the range [0, 5000]
- -5000 <= Node.val <= 5000

examples.explanation: The linked list is reversed.

hints: Use three pointers: prev, current, next
Iterate through the list reversing pointers
Can also be solved recursively

questions.title: Valid Parentheses
questions.introduction: Given a string s containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '[' and ']', determine if the input string is valid.
questions.problemStatement:
An input string is valid if:
1. Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets.
2. Open brackets must be closed in the correct order.
3. Every close bracket has a corresponding open bracket of the same type.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^4
- s consists of parentheses only '()[]{}',

examples.explanation: All brackets are properly closed.
Brackets are not closed in correct order.

hints: Use a stack data structure
Push opening brackets onto stack
For closing brackets, check if they match stack top

questions.title: Three Sum
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, return all the triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that i != j, i != k, and j != k, and nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0. Notice that the solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.
questions.problemStatement:
Find all unique triplets in the array which gives the sum of zero.

Constraints:
- 3 <= nums.length <= 3000
- -10^5 <= nums[i] <= 10^5

examples.explanation: nums[0] + nums[1] + nums[2] = (-1) + 0 + 1 = 0. nums[1] + nums[2] + nums[4] = 0 + 1 + (-1) = 0. nums[0] + nums[3] + nums[4] = (-1) + 2 + (-1) = 0. The distinct triplets are [-1,0,1] and [-1,-1,2].
The only possible triplet does not sum up to 0.
The only possible triplet sums up to 0.

hints: Sort the array first to use two pointers efficiently
Fix one element and use two pointers to find the other two
Skip duplicate elements to avoid duplicate triplets

questions.title: Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order, remove the duplicates in-place such that each unique element appears only once. The relative order of the elements should be kept the same. Return the number of unique elements.
questions.problemStatement:
Remove duplicates from a sorted array in-place and return the count of unique elements.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 10^4
- -100 <= nums[i] <= 100
- nums is sorted in non-decreasing order

examples.explanation: Your function should return k = 2, with the first two elements of nums being 1 and 2 respectively.
Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements being 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4.

hints: Use a slow pointer to track position for unique elements
Use a fast pointer to scan through the array
Only move slow pointer when a new unique element is found

questions.title: Trapping Rain Water
questions.introduction: Given n non-negative integers representing an elevation map where the width of each bar is 1, compute how much water it can trap after raining.
questions.problemStatement:
Calculate the total amount of rainwater that can be trapped between the bars.

Constraints:
- n == height.length
- 1 <= n <= 2 * 10^4
- 0 <= height[i] <= 10^5

examples.explanation: The elevation map is represented by array [0,1,0,2,1,0,1,3,2,1,2,1]. In this case, 6 units of rain water are being trapped.
9 units of rain water are trapped between the bars.

hints: Water at any position depends on the minimum of max heights on both sides
Use two pointers from both ends
Track leftMax and rightMax as you move pointers inward

questions.title: Valid Palindrome
questions.introduction: A phrase is a palindrome if, after converting all uppercase letters into lowercase letters and removing all non-alphanumeric characters, it reads the same forward and backward. Alphanumeric characters include letters and numbers.
questions.problemStatement:
Given a string s, return true if it is a palindrome, or false otherwise.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 2 * 10^5
- s consists only of printable ASCII characters

examples.input: s = "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama"
examples.explanation: "amanaplanacanalpanama" is a palindrome.
"raceacar" is not a palindrome.
After removing non-alphanumeric characters, s is an empty string. An empty string is a palindrome.

hints: Use two pointers: one at start, one at end
Skip non-alphanumeric characters
Compare characters case-insensitively

questions.title: Move Zeroes
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, move all 0's to the end of it while maintaining the relative order of the non-zero elements. Note that you must do this in-place without making a copy of the array.
questions.problemStatement:
Move all zeros to the end of the array while maintaining relative order of non-zero elements.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^4
- -2^31 <= nums[i] <= 2^31 - 1

examples.explanation: All zeros are moved to the end while maintaining order of non-zero elements.
Single zero stays in place.

hints: Use a slow pointer to track position for non-zero elements
Use a fast pointer to find non-zero elements
Swap elements when fast pointer finds non-zero

questions.title: Sort Colors
questions.introduction: Given an array nums with n objects colored red, white, or blue, sort them in-place so that objects of the same color are adjacent, with the colors in the order red, white, and blue. We will use the integers 0, 1, and 2 to represent the color red, white, and blue, respectively.
questions.problemStatement:
Sort the array containing only 0s, 1s, and 2s in-place without using the library's sort function.

Constraints:
- n == nums.length
- 1 <= n <= 300
- nums[i] is either 0, 1, or 2

examples.explanation: Array is sorted with 0s first, then 1s, then 2s.
Array is sorted in ascending order.

hints: This is the Dutch National Flag problem
Use three pointers: low, mid, and high
Swap elements based on value at mid pointer

questions.title: 3Sum Closest
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums of length n and an integer target, find three integers in nums such that the sum is closest to target. Return the sum of the three integers.
questions.problemStatement:
Find three integers whose sum is closest to the target and return that sum.

Constraints:
- 3 <= nums.length <= 500
- -1000 <= nums[i] <= 1000
- -10^4 <= target <= 10^4

examples.explanation: The sum that is closest to the target is 2. (-1 + 2 + 1 = 2).
The sum that is closest to the target is 0. (0 + 0 + 0 = 0).

hints: Sort the array first
Fix one element and use two pointers for remaining two
Track the closest sum and update when a closer sum is found

questions.title: Merge Sorted Array
questions.introduction: You are given two integer arrays nums1 and nums2, sorted in non-decreasing order, and two integers m and n, representing the number of elements in nums1 and nums2 respectively. Merge nums2 into nums1 as one sorted array.
questions.problemStatement:
Merge nums2 into nums1 in-place. nums1 has enough space (size m + n) to hold additional elements from nums2.

Constraints:
- nums1.length == m + n
- nums2.length == n
- 0 <= m, n <= 200
- 1 <= m + n <= 200
- -10^9 <= nums1[i], nums2[j] <= 10^9

examples.explanation: The arrays we are merging are [1,2,3] and [2,5,6]. The result is [1,2,2,3,5,6].
The arrays we are merging are [1] and []. The result is [1].

hints: Start from the end of both arrays
Compare elements and place larger one at the end of nums1
Work backwards to avoid overwriting elements

questions.title: Squares of a Sorted Array
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order, return an array of the squares of each number sorted in non-decreasing order.
questions.problemStatement:
Return an array of squares of each number in sorted order.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^4
- -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4
- nums is sorted in non-decreasing order

examples.explanation: After squaring, the array becomes [16,1,0,9,100]. After sorting, it becomes [0,1,9,16,100].
After squaring and sorting, the result is [4,9,9,49,121].

hints: The largest squares will be at either end of the array
Use two pointers at both ends
Fill result array from the end to the beginning

questions.title: 4Sum
questions.introduction: Given an array nums of n integers, return an array of all the unique quadruplets [nums[a], nums[b], nums[c], nums[d]] such that a, b, c, and d are distinct indices and nums[a] + nums[b] + nums[c] + nums[d] == target.
questions.problemStatement:
Find all unique quadruplets that sum up to the target.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 200
- -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9
- -10^9 <= target <= 10^9

examples.explanation: All unique quadruplets that sum to 0.
Only one unique quadruplet sums to 8.

hints: Sort the array first
Fix two elements and use two pointers for remaining two
Skip duplicates at each level to avoid duplicate quadruplets

questions.title: Reverse String
questions.introduction: Write a function that reverses a string. The input string is given as an array of characters s. You must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory.
questions.problemStatement:
Reverse the string in-place.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- s[i] is a printable ASCII character

examples.explanation: The string is reversed in-place.
The string is reversed in-place.

hints: Use two pointers: one at start, one at end
Swap characters at both pointers
Move pointers towards center

questions.title: Two Sum II - Input Array Is Sorted
questions.introduction: Given a 1-indexed array of integers numbers that is already sorted in non-decreasing order, find two numbers such that they add up to a specific target number. Return the indices of the two numbers, index1 and index2, added by one.
questions.problemStatement:
Find two numbers in a sorted array that add up to the target. Return their 1-indexed positions.

Constraints:
- 2 <= numbers.length <= 3 * 10^4
- -1000 <= numbers[i] <= 1000
- numbers is sorted in non-decreasing order
- -1000 <= target <= 1000
- Only one valid answer exists

examples.explanation: The sum of 2 and 7 is 9. Therefore, index1 = 1, index2 = 2. We return [1, 2].
The sum of 2 and 4 is 6. Therefore index1 = 1, index2 = 3. We return [1, 3].
The sum of -1 and 0 is -1. Therefore index1 = 1, index2 = 2. We return [1, 2].

hints: Use two pointers: one at start, one at end
If sum is too large, move right pointer left
If sum is too small, move left pointer right

questions.title: Reverse Vowels of a String
questions.introduction: Given a string s, reverse only all the vowels in the string and return it. The vowels are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', and 'u', and they can appear in both lower and upper cases, more than once.
questions.problemStatement:
Reverse only the vowels in the given string.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 3 * 10^5
- s consist of printable ASCII characters

examples.explanation: The vowels are 'e' and 'o'. After reversing, they become 'o' and 'e'.
The vowels are 'e', 'e', 'o', 'e'. After reversing, they become 'e', 'o', 'e', 'e'.

hints: Use two pointers from both ends
Skip non-vowel characters
Swap when both pointers point to vowels

questions.title: Is Subsequence
questions.introduction: Given two strings s and t, return true if s is a subsequence of t, or false otherwise. A subsequence of a string is a new string that is formed from the original string by deleting some (can be none) of the characters without disturbing the relative positions of the remaining characters.
questions.problemStatement:
Determine if string s is a subsequence of string t.

Constraints:
- 0 <= s.length <= 100
- 0 <= t.length <= 10^4
- s and t consist only of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: 'a', 'b', 'c' appear in t in the same order.
'x' does not appear in t.

hints: Use two pointers, one for each string
Move pointer in s only when characters match
Always move pointer in t

questions.title: String Compression
questions.introduction: Given an array of characters chars, compress it using the following algorithm: Begin with an empty string s. For each group of consecutive repeating characters in chars, append the character followed by the group's length if the length is greater than 1.
questions.problemStatement:
Compress the character array in-place and return the new length.

Constraints:
- 1 <= chars.length <= 2000
- chars[i] is a lowercase English letter, uppercase English letter, digit, or symbol

examples.explanation: The groups are "aa", "bb", and "ccc". This compresses to "a2b2c3".
The only group is "a", which remains uncompressed since it appears only once.
The groups are "a" and "bbbbbbbbbbbb". This compresses to "ab12".

hints: Use read and write pointers
Count consecutive characters with read pointer
Write character and count with write pointer

questions.title: Boats to Save People
questions.introduction: You are given an array people where people[i] is the weight of the ith person, and an infinite number of boats where each boat can carry a maximum weight of limit. Each boat carries at most two people at the same time, provided the sum of the weight of those people is at most limit.
questions.problemStatement:
Return the minimum number of boats to carry every given person.

Constraints:
- 1 <= people.length <= 5 * 10^4
- 1 <= people[i] <= limit <= 3 * 10^4

examples.explanation: 1 boat can carry both people (1+2 <= 3).

hints: Sort the array first
Try to pair the lightest with the heaviest person
Use two pointers from both ends

questions.title: Long Pressed Name
questions.introduction: Your friend is typing his name into a keyboard. Sometimes, when typing a character c, the key might get long pressed, and the character will be typed 1 or more times. You examine the typed characters of the keyboard. Return True if it is possible that it was your friends name, with some characters (possibly none) being long pressed.
questions.problemStatement:
Determine if typed string could be a long-pressed version of name.

Constraints:
- 1 <= name.length, typed.length <= 1000
- name and typed consist of only lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: 'a' and 'e' in 'alex' were long pressed.
'e' must have been pressed twice, but it was not in the typed output.
Characters were long pressed appropriately.

hints: Use two pointers, one for each string
Characters must match in order
Extra characters in typed must match previous character

questions.title: Rotate Array
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, rotate the array to the right by k steps, where k is non-negative.
questions.problemStatement:
Rotate the array to the right by k steps in-place.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- -2^31 <= nums[i] <= 2^31 - 1
- 0 <= k <= 10^5

examples.explanation: Rotate right by 2 steps.

hints: Reverse the entire array first
Reverse the first k elements
Reverse the remaining n-k elements

questions.title: Shortest Unsorted Continuous Subarray
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, you need to find one continuous subarray such that if you only sort this subarray in non-decreasing order, then the whole array will be sorted in non-decreasing order.
questions.problemStatement:
Return the shortest such subarray and output its length.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^4
- -10^5 <= nums[i] <= 10^5

examples.explanation: You need to sort [6, 4, 8, 10, 9] in ascending order to make the whole array sorted.
The array is already sorted.
Single element array is always sorted.

hints: Find the rightmost element smaller than some element on its left
Find the leftmost element larger than some element on its right
The subarray between these positions needs sorting

questions.title: Compare Version Numbers
questions.introduction: Given two version numbers, version1 and version2, compare them. Version numbers consist of one or more revisions joined by a dot '.'. Each revision consists of digits and may contain leading zeros.
questions.problemStatement:
Compare two version strings. Return -1 if version1 < version2, 1 if version1 > version2, otherwise return 0.

Constraints:
- 1 <= version1.length, version2.length <= 500
- version1 and version2 only contain digits and '.'

examples.explanation: Ignoring leading zeroes, both "01" and "001" represent the same integer "1".
version1 does not specify revision 2, which means it is treated as "0".
version1's revision 0 is "0", while version2's revision 0 is "1". 0 < 1, so version1 < version2.

hints: Use two pointers to traverse both version strings
Extract integer values between dots
Treat missing revisions as 0

questions.title: Subarray Product Less Than K
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers nums and an integer k, return the number of contiguous subarrays where the product of all the elements in the subarray is strictly less than k.
questions.problemStatement:
Count subarrays with product less than k.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 10^4
- 1 <= nums[i] <= 1000
- 0 <= k <= 10^6

examples.explanation: The 8 subarrays with product less than 100 are: [10], [5], [2], [6], [10,5], [5,2], [2,6], [5,2,6].
No subarray has product less than 0.

hints: Use sliding window with two pointers
Expand right pointer and multiply product
Shrink from left when product >= k

questions.title: Next Permutation
questions.introduction: A permutation of an array of integers is an arrangement of its members into a sequence or linear order. The next permutation of an array of integers is the next lexicographically greater permutation of its integer.
questions.problemStatement:
Rearrange numbers into the lexicographically next greater permutation. If no such arrangement exists, rearrange into the lowest possible order (sorted in ascending order).

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 100
- 0 <= nums[i] <= 100

examples.explanation: The next permutation of [1,2,3] is [1,3,2].
No next permutation exists, so return the smallest permutation.
The next permutation of [1,1,5] is [1,5,1].

hints: Find the first decreasing element from the right
Swap it with the smallest element larger than it on its right
Reverse the suffix after the swap position

questions.title: Remove Element
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums and an integer val, remove all occurrences of val in nums in-place. The order of the elements may be changed. Then return the number of elements in nums which are not equal to val.
questions.problemStatement:
Remove all occurrences of val in-place and return the count of remaining elements.

Constraints:
- 0 <= nums.length <= 100
- 0 <= nums[i] <= 50
- 0 <= val <= 100

examples.explanation: Your function should return k = 2, with the first two elements of nums being 2.
Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements containing 0, 0, 1, 3, and 4.

hints: Use two pointers: one for iterating, one for placing valid elements
Swap element to end if it equals val
Alternatively, overwrite val elements with non-val elements

questions.title: Valid Palindrome II
questions.introduction: Given a string s, return true if the s can be palindrome after deleting at most one character from it.
questions.problemStatement:
Determine if string can become a palindrome by removing at most one character.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- s consists of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: Already a palindrome.
You could delete the character 'c' to get "aba".
Cannot make it a palindrome by removing one character.

hints: Use two pointers from both ends
When characters don't match, try skipping left or right character
Check if remaining substring is a palindrome

questions.title: Partition Labels
questions.introduction: You are given a string s. We want to partition the string into as many parts as possible so that each letter appears in at most one part. Return a list of integers representing the size of these parts.
questions.problemStatement:
Partition string so each letter appears in at most one part. Return list of partition sizes.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 500
- s consists of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: The partition is "ababcbaca", "defegde", "hijhklij". Each letter appears in at most one part.
The entire string forms one partition.

hints: Find the last occurrence of each character first
Use two pointers to track current partition boundaries
Extend partition end when encountering a character that appears later

questions.title: Minimum Window Substring
questions.introduction: Given two strings s and t of lengths m and n respectively, return the minimum window substring of s such that every character in t (including duplicates) is included in the window. If there is no such substring, return the empty string.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the minimum window in s which contains all characters of t.

Constraints:
- m == s.length
- n == t.length
- 1 <= m, n <= 10^5
- s and t consist of uppercase and lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: The minimum window substring "BANC" includes 'A', 'B', and 'C' from string t.
The entire string s is the minimum window.
Both 'a's from t must be included in the window. Since s has only one 'a', return empty string.

hints: Use sliding window with two pointers
Expand right pointer to include all characters of t
Shrink from left to find minimum window

questions.title: Intersection of Two Arrays II
questions.introduction: Given two integer arrays nums1 and nums2, return an array of their intersection. Each element in the result must appear as many times as it shows in both arrays and you may return the result in any order.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the intersection of two arrays, including duplicates.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums1.length, nums2.length <= 1000
- 0 <= nums1[i], nums2[i] <= 1000

examples.explanation: 2 appears twice in both arrays.
4 and 9 appear in both arrays. Order doesn't matter.

hints: Sort both arrays first
Use two pointers to find common elements
Move pointer with smaller value forward
questions.timeComplexity: O(n log n + m log m)

questions.title: Reverse Words in a String
questions.introduction: Given an input string s, reverse the order of the words. A word is defined as a sequence of non-space characters. The words in s will be separated by at least one space. Return a string of the words in reverse order concatenated by a single space.
questions.problemStatement:
Reverse the order of words in the string. Remove leading/trailing spaces and reduce multiple spaces between words to a single space.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^4
- s contains English letters (upper-case and lower-case), digits, and spaces ' '
- There is at least one word in s

examples.explanation: Words are reversed in order.
Leading/trailing spaces removed, words reversed.
Multiple spaces reduced to single space, words reversed.

hints: Reverse the entire string first
Then reverse each individual word
Use two pointers to identify word boundaries

questions.title: Product of Array Except Self
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums, return an array answer such that answer[i] is equal to the product of all the elements of nums except nums[i]. The product of any prefix or suffix of nums is guaranteed to fit in a 32-bit integer. You must write an algorithm that runs in O(n) time and without using the division operation.
questions.problemStatement:
Return an array where each element is the product of all other elements.

Constraints:
- 2 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- -30 <= nums[i] <= 30
- The product of any prefix or suffix of nums fits in a 32-bit integer

examples.explanation: Products calculated excluding each element.

hints: Calculate prefix products from left to right
Calculate suffix products from right to left
Multiply prefix and suffix for each position

questions.title: Maximum Average Subarray I
questions.introduction: You are given an integer array nums consisting of n elements, and an integer k. Find a contiguous subarray whose length is equal to k that has the maximum average value and return this value.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the contiguous subarray of length k with the maximum average.

Constraints:
- n == nums.length
- 1 <= k <= n <= 10^5
- -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4

examples.explanation: Maximum average is (12 - 5 - 6 + 50) / 4 = 51 / 4 = 12.75
Only one element, so the average is 5.

hints: Use a fixed-size sliding window of size k
Calculate sum of first k elements
Slide window by adding next element and removing first element

questions.title: Minimum Size Subarray Sum
questions.introduction: Given an array of positive integers nums and a positive integer target, return the minimal length of a subarray whose sum is greater than or equal to target. If there is no such subarray, return 0 instead.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the minimal length subarray with sum >= target.

Constraints:
- 1 <= target <= 10^9
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- 1 <= nums[i] <= 10^4

examples.explanation: The subarray [4,3] has the minimal length under the problem constraint.
The subarray [4] has sum >= 4 with minimal length.
No subarray has sum >= 11.

hints: Use a variable-size sliding window
Expand window by adding elements to reach target
Shrink window from left while sum >= target

questions.title: Longest Repeating Character Replacement
questions.introduction: You are given a string s and an integer k. You can choose any character of the string and change it to any other uppercase English character. You can perform this operation at most k times. Return the length of the longest substring containing the same letter you can get after performing the above operations.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest substring with same characters after at most k replacements.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- s consists of only uppercase English letters
- 0 <= k <= s.length

examples.explanation: Replace the two 'A's with two 'B's or vice versa.
Replace the one 'A' in the middle with 'B' and form "AABBBBA". The substring "BBBB" has the longest repeating letters, which is 4.

hints: Use sliding window with character frequency count
Track the count of the most frequent character in window
Window is valid if (window_size - max_freq) <= k

questions.title: Permutation in String
questions.introduction: Given two strings s1 and s2, return true if s2 contains a permutation of s1, or false otherwise. In other words, return true if one of s1's permutations is the substring of s2.
questions.problemStatement:
Check if s2 contains any permutation of s1 as a substring.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s1.length, s2.length <= 10^4
- s1 and s2 consist of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: s2 contains one permutation of s1 ("ba").
s2 does not contain any permutation of s1.

hints: Use a fixed-size sliding window of length s1
Compare character frequencies in window with s1
Use array of size 26 for frequency counting

questions.title: Find All Anagrams in a String
questions.introduction: Given two strings s and p, return an array of all the start indices of p's anagrams in s. You may return the answer in any order. An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.
questions.problemStatement:
Find all starting indices of anagrams of p in s.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length, p.length <= 3 * 10^4
- s and p consist of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: The substring starting at index 0 is "cba", which is an anagram of "abc". The substring starting at index 6 is "bac", which is an anagram of "abc".
The substrings "ab", "ba", "ab" starting at indices 0, 1, 2 are all anagrams of "ab".

hints: Use a fixed-size sliding window of length p
Compare character frequencies using arrays
Slide window and update frequencies incrementally

questions.title: Sliding Window Maximum
questions.introduction: You are given an array of integers nums, there is a sliding window of size k which is moving from the very left of the array to the very right. You can only see the k numbers in the window. Each time the sliding window moves right by one position. Return the max sliding window.
questions.problemStatement:
Return the maximum element in each sliding window of size k.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4
- 1 <= k <= nums.length

examples.explanation: Only one element in the window.

hints: Use a deque to store indices of useful elements
Keep deque in decreasing order of values
Remove elements outside the current window

questions.title: Fruit Into Baskets
questions.introduction: You are visiting a farm that has a single row of fruit trees arranged from left to right. You will be given an integer array fruits where fruits[i] is the type of fruit the ith tree produces. You have two baskets, and each basket can only hold a single type of fruit. Return the maximum number of fruits you can pick.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest subarray containing at most 2 distinct fruit types.

Constraints:
- 1 <= fruits.length <= 10^5
- 0 <= fruits[i] < fruits.length

examples.explanation: We can pick from all 3 trees.
We can pick from trees [1,2,2]. If we started at tree 0, we would only pick [0,1].
We can pick from trees [2,3,2,2]. If we started at tree 0, we would only pick [1,2].

hints: This is longest subarray with at most 2 distinct elements
Use sliding window with a hash map
Shrink window when more than 2 types exist

questions.title: Max Consecutive Ones III
questions.introduction: Given a binary array nums and an integer k, return the maximum number of consecutive 1's in the array if you can flip at most k 0's.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest subarray of 1s after flipping at most k zeros.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- nums[i] is either 0 or 1
- 0 <= k <= nums.length

examples.explanation: Flip nums[5] and nums[10] to get the longest consecutive 1s: [1,1,1,0,0,1,1,1,1,1,1]
Flip 3 zeros to get 10 consecutive 1s.

hints: Use sliding window approach
Track the count of zeros in current window
Shrink window when zeros count exceeds k

questions.title: Longest Substring with At Most K Distinct Characters
questions.introduction: Given a string s and an integer k, return the length of the longest substring of s that contains at most k distinct characters.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest substring with at most k distinct characters.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 5 * 10^4
- 0 <= k <= 50
- s consists of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: The substring is "ece" with length 3.
The substring is "aa" with length 2.
Cannot have a substring with 0 distinct characters that contains any letters.

hints: Use sliding window with a hash map for character counts
Expand window and add characters to map
Shrink window when distinct characters exceed k

questions.title: Minimum Window Substring
questions.introduction: Given two strings s and t of lengths m and n respectively, return the minimum window substring of s such that every character in t (including duplicates) is included in the window. If there is no such substring, return the empty string.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the minimum window in s which contains all characters of t.

Constraints:
- m == s.length
- n == t.length
- 1 <= m, n <= 10^5
- s and t consist of uppercase and lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: The minimum window substring "BANC" includes 'A', 'B', and 'C' from string t.
The entire string s is the minimum window.
Both 'a's from t must be included. Since s has only one 'a', return empty string.

hints: Use two hash maps: one for t, one for current window
Track how many characters are satisfied
Shrink window when all characters are found

questions.title: Grumpy Bookstore Owner
questions.introduction: There is a bookstore owner that has a store open for n minutes. Every minute, some number of customers enter the store. You are given an integer array customers where customers[i] is the number of customers at minute i. The owner is grumpy for some minutes indicated by a binary array grumpy. When grumpy[i] is 1, the owner is grumpy during minute i. The owner can use a secret technique to not be grumpy for k consecutive minutes, but can only use it once.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the maximum number of satisfied customers.

Constraints:
- n == customers.length == grumpy.length
- 1 <= n <= 2 * 10^4
- 0 <= customers[i] <= 1000
- grumpy[i] is either 0 or 1
- 1 <= k <= n

examples.explanation: Use the technique from minute 3 to 5. Maximum satisfied = 1 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 7 + 5 - 2 = 16.
Owner is not grumpy, so all customers are satisfied.

hints: First calculate base satisfaction (when owner is not grumpy)
Use sliding window to find the best k minutes to suppress grumpiness
Track additional customers saved by suppressing grumpiness

questions.title: Contains Duplicate II
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return true if there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that nums[i] == nums[j] and abs(i - j) <= k.
questions.problemStatement:
Check if array contains duplicate within k distance.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9
- 0 <= k <= 10^5

examples.explanation: nums[0] == nums[3] and abs(0-3) = 3 <= 3.
nums[2] == nums[3] and abs(2-3) = 1 <= 1.
No duplicate exists within distance 2.

hints: Use a sliding window with a set
Maintain a set of elements in the last k positions
Check if new element exists in set before adding

questions.title: Repeated DNA Sequences
questions.introduction: The DNA sequence is composed of a series of nucleotides abbreviated as 'A', 'C', 'G', and 'T'. Given a string s that represents a DNA sequence, return all the 10-letter-long sequences (substrings) that occur more than once in a DNA molecule. You may return the answer in any order.
questions.problemStatement:
Find all 10-letter sequences that appear more than once.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- s[i] is either 'A', 'C', 'G', or 'T'

examples.explanation: Both "AAAAACCCCC" and "CCCCCAAAAA" appear more than once.
"AAAAAAAAAA" appears twice.

hints: Use a fixed-size sliding window of length 10
Use a hash set to track seen sequences
Use another set to track repeated sequences

questions.title: Subarrays with K Different Integers
questions.introduction: Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return the number of good subarrays of nums. A good array is an array where the number of different integers in that array is exactly k.
questions.problemStatement:
Count subarrays with exactly k distinct integers.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 2 * 10^4
- 1 <= nums[i], k <= nums.length

examples.explanation: Subarrays with exactly 2 distinct integers: [1,2], [2,1], [1,2], [2,3], [1,2,1], [2,1,2], [1,2,1,2].
Subarrays with exactly 3 distinct integers: [1,2,1,3], [2,1,3], [1,3,4].

hints: exactly(k) = atMost(k) - atMost(k-1)
Use sliding window to count subarrays with at most k distinct
Apply the formula to get exactly k

questions.title: Maximum Points You Can Obtain from Cards
questions.introduction: There are several cards arranged in a row, and each card has an associated number of points. The points are given in the integer array cardPoints. In one step, you can take one card from the beginning or from the end of the row. You have to take exactly k cards. Your score is the sum of the points of the cards you have taken.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the maximum score obtainable by taking k cards from either end.

Constraints:
- 1 <= cardPoints.length <= 10^5
- 1 <= cardPoints[i] <= 10^4
- 1 <= k <= cardPoints.length

examples.explanation: Take the last 3 cards: 1 + 6 + 5 = 12.
Take any 2 cards: 2 + 2 = 4.
Take all cards for maximum sum.

hints: Find minimum sum subarray of size n-k in the middle
Answer is total sum minus this minimum subarray
Use sliding window to find minimum subarray sum

questions.title: Binary Subarrays With Sum
questions.introduction: Given a binary array nums and an integer goal, return the number of non-empty subarrays with a sum goal.
questions.problemStatement:
Count subarrays with sum equal to goal.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 10^4
- nums[i] is either 0 or 1
- 0 <= goal <= nums.length

examples.explanation: All subarrays of zeros have sum 0.

hints: Use atMost(goal) - atMost(goal-1) technique
Or use prefix sum with hash map
Count subarrays ending at each position

questions.title: Count Number of Nice Subarrays
questions.introduction: Given an array of integers nums and an integer k. A continuous subarray is called nice if there are k odd numbers on it. Return the number of nice sub-arrays.
questions.problemStatement:
Count subarrays with exactly k odd numbers.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 50000
- 1 <= nums[i] <= 10^5
- 1 <= k <= nums.length

examples.explanation: The subarrays with 3 odd numbers are [1,1,2,1] and [1,2,1,1].
There are no odd numbers in the array.
Count all subarrays with exactly 2 odd numbers.

hints: Convert problem: treat odd as 1, even as 0
Use atMost(k) - atMost(k-1) technique
Or use prefix sum approach

questions.title: Get Equal Substrings Within Budget
questions.introduction: You are given two strings s and t of the same length and an integer maxCost. You want to change s to t. Changing the ith character of s to ith character of t costs |s[i] - t[i]|. Return the maximum length of a substring of s that can be changed to be the same as the corresponding substring of t with a cost less than or equal to maxCost.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest substring of s that can be changed to match t within the cost budget.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- t.length == s.length
- 0 <= maxCost <= 10^6
- s and t consist of only lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: "abc" can change to "bcd" with cost 1+1+1 = 3.
Each character requires cost 2 to change, so max length is 1.
Only matching characters 'a' can be included.

hints: Create an array of costs for each position
Use sliding window to find longest subarray with sum <= maxCost
Shrink window when cost exceeds budget

questions.title: Longest Subarray of 1's After Deleting One Element
questions.introduction: Given a binary array nums, you should delete one element from it. Return the size of the longest non-empty subarray containing only 1's in the resulting array. Return 0 if there is no such subarray.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest subarray of 1s after deleting exactly one element.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- nums[i] is either 0 or 1

examples.explanation: After deleting the 0, we get [1,1,1] of length 3.
After deleting the 0 at index 4, we get [0,1,1,1,1,1,0,1].
You must delete one element, leaving [1,1].

hints: Similar to Max Consecutive Ones III with k=1
Use sliding window with at most one 0
Result is window size - 1 (since we must delete one)

questions.title: Substring with Concatenation of All Words
questions.introduction: You are given a string s and an array of strings words. All the strings of words are of the same length. A concatenated substring in s is a substring that contains all the strings of any permutation of words concatenated.
questions.problemStatement:
Find all starting indices of substrings that are concatenations of all words.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^4
- 1 <= words.length <= 5000
- 1 <= words[i].length <= 30
- s and words[i] consist of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: Substrings starting at 0 and 9 are "barfoo" and "foobar".
No valid substring exists.
Substrings at indices 6, 9, 12 are valid concatenations.

hints: Use a sliding window of size (word_count * word_length)
Use hash maps to count words
Check each possible starting position modulo word_length
questions.timeComplexity: O(n * k) where k is word length
questions.spaceComplexity: O(m * k) where m is number of words

questions.title: Maximum Number of Vowels in a Substring of Given Length
questions.introduction: Given a string s and an integer k, return the maximum number of vowel letters in any substring of s with length k. Vowel letters in English are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', and 'u'.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the maximum number of vowels in any substring of length k.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 10^5
- s consists of lowercase English letters
- 1 <= k <= s.length

examples.explanation: The substring "iii" contains 3 vowels.
Any substring of length 2 contains 2 vowels.
"lee", "eet" and "ode" each contain 2 vowels.

hints: Use a fixed-size sliding window of size k
Count vowels in initial window
Update count as window slides

questions.title: Longest Turbulent Subarray
questions.introduction: Given an integer array arr, return the length of a maximum size turbulent subarray of arr. A subarray is turbulent if the comparison sign flips between each adjacent pair of elements in the subarray.
questions.problemStatement:
Find the longest turbulent subarray (alternating greater/less than comparisons).

Constraints:
- 1 <= arr.length <= 4 * 10^4
- 0 <= arr[i] <= 10^9

examples.explanation: arr[1] > arr[2] < arr[3] > arr[4] < arr[5] forms a turbulent subarray of length 5.
Only adjacent pairs can form turbulent subarrays.
Single element array.

hints: Use sliding window with comparison state tracking
Track if last comparison was > or <
Reset window when comparison pattern breaks

questions.title: Number of Substrings Containing All Three Characters
questions.introduction: Given a string s consisting only of characters a, b and c. Return the number of substrings containing at least one occurrence of all these characters a, b and c.
questions.problemStatement:
Count substrings containing at least one of each: 'a', 'b', and 'c'.

Constraints:
- 3 <= s.length <= 5 * 10^4
- s only consists of a, b or c characters

examples.explanation: Substrings containing a, b, c are: "abc", "abca", "abcab", "abcabc", "bca", "bcab", "bcabc", "cab", "cabc", "abc".
Substrings are "aaacb", "aacb", "acb".
Only "abc" contains all three characters.

hints: For each position, find the smallest valid window ending there
All longer substrings from that window will also be valid
Use sliding window and count contributions

questions.title: Minimum Operations to Reduce X to Zero
questions.introduction: You are given an integer array nums and an integer x. In one operation, you can either remove the leftmost or the rightmost element from the array nums and subtract its value from x. Return the minimum number of operations to reduce x to exactly 0, or -1 if not possible.
questions.problemStatement:
Find minimum elements to remove from ends to make sum equal to x.

Constraints:
- 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
- 1 <= nums[i] <= 10^4
- 1 <= x <= 10^9

examples.explanation: Remove 2 and 3 from the right to get sum 5.
Cannot achieve sum 4 from any combination of ends.
Remove 3,2 from left and 1,1,3 from right.

hints: Reframe: find longest middle subarray with sum = total - x
Use sliding window to find this middle subarray
Answer is n - length of this subarray
